title: Shivering Children, Pricier Spandex: The Impact of China’s Energy Stumble
summary: China tried this fall to replace much of its coal with natural gas. But with supplies running short, chemical factories have been closed.

title: BP, Once a Renewables Leader, Bets $200 Million on Solar
summary: The energy giant is returning to a business it backed away from after the costly and reputation-tarnishing Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: What Needs to Happen Before Electric Cars Take Over the World
summary: Electric vehicles have only a tiny market share, but the auto industry is betting billions that they will soon be as cheap as conventional cars.

title: Carmakers Try to Keep Waste Out of the Ground as Well as the Air
summary: Automakers have been trying for years to stop sending anything to landfills. Now they are using other would-be trash to make parts.

title: Shell, Seeking to Curb Its Carbon Footprint, Buys Electricity Provider
summary: The acquisition of First Utility was an indication that Europe’s largest oil company was responding to pressures to shift from fossil fuels.

title: Fighting Climate Change, One Laundry Load at a Time
summary: Experts in the study of fungi are playing a bigger role in improving laundry detergents and, by extension, leading efforts to cut energy use.

title: Deep Freeze in U.S. Creates Heating Squeeze for Homeowners and Utilities
summary: Heating-oil providers are working overtime and power generators are switching from natural gas to coal and petroleum as bitter temperatures grip much of the country.

title: Companies Warn of Hits From Tax Cuts. Don’t Be Fooled.
summary: Companies are expected to report billions of dollars in short-term losses stemming from the new tax law. But they are a prelude to much larger profits.

title: After Dow 25,000, the Party Has to End. But When?
summary: Market veterans say that stocks are overvalued and that a downturn is overdue. The question is how messy it will be, and how investors should prepare.

title: U.S. Job Market’s Strength Is Allowing More to Share in Pay Gains
summary: Though wages are growing sluggishly over all, some of the strongest increases are in blue-collar and service industries as employers vie for help.

title: Macron Holds a Climate Summit, and Trump Casts a Shadow
summary: Leaders, businesspeople and investors from around the world gathered near Paris at the invitation of the French president, who warned “we are losing the battle” against climate change.

title: Fancy Sausages and a $2 Million Bribe: A Trial Uncovers Kremlin Infighting
summary: Aleksei V. Ulyukayev, a former economy minister, has been convicted of corruption after a power struggle with the head of the state oil company.

title: World’s Most Expensive Home? Another Bauble for a Saudi Prince
summary: A $300 million chateau is one of a string of extravagant purchases for a prince who is cracking down on ill-gotten wealth and preaching fiscal austerity.

title: 17 Postcards From Our Correspondents Around the World in 2017
summary: “Journals” are a longstanding New York Times feature that tries to take readers to new places. These were some of our favorites from the year.

title: Once a Cash Cow, Venezuela’s Oil Company Now Verges on Collapse
summary: The deepening troubles threaten to further destabilize a nation facing a dire recession and unbridled crime, as well as food and medicine shortages.

title: Scattered Protests Erupt in Iran Over Economic Woes
summary: Demonstrations spread to Tehran and other cities, highlighting weak economic conditions in a country where youth unemployment is over 40 percent.

title: Rouhani Urges Calm in Iran as Protests Continue
summary: Two demonstrators were reported killed in recent days as protests quickly grew into a nationwide outpouring of anger.

title: Kim Jong-un Offers North Korea’s Hand to South, While Chiding U.S.
summary: He proposed talks with South Korea to discuss the North’s participation in the Winter Games, and boasted of having a “nuclear button” on his desk.

title: China’s Ambitious New ‘Port’: Landlocked Kazakhstan
summary: In a wilderness of frozen desert, China and Kazakhstan are reviving a Silk Road land bridge between Asia and Europe, reshaping trade and geopolitics.

title: Kim Jong-un’s Overture Could Drive a Wedge Between South Korea and the U.S.
summary: North Korea’s surprising call for dialogue with the South may undercut the Trump administration’s tough approach.

title: Deadly Iran Protests Prompt Warning of Harsher Response
summary: The rallies are the biggest in years, and are breaking out in areas once reliably loyal to the government.

title: Turkey Calls U.S. Conviction of Banker ‘Scandalous’
summary: Still, the volley of criticism seemed rote as the trial left President Recep Tayyip Erdogan largely unscathed.

title: Maduro Cuts Off Venezuela’s Air and Sea Traffic With 3 Island Neighbors
summary: The shutoff temporarily halts flights and ship traffic to and from Aruba, Bonaire and Curaçao, three islands that host black markets for Venezuelan contraband.
